comments.commentBody: Russia was one demographic Hillary didn't pander to - she messed up.  Bet the next presidential campaign will be conducted on manual  typewriters.
She did not pander to Comey either.

Would like to communicate offline if possible.  Key to understanding disdain working class feels towards more educated (cultural elites, public intellectuals, professionals) is demise of alternative upward mobility path to the higher education / meritocracy path.  Within large manufactural firms with unions, internal labor markets (ILMs) were created that created opportunities for those without college degrees.  With demise of ILMs, all that is left is higher ed. route, and those who have not and often can not compete in the meritocratic systems are worse off.  Workers feel that those with higher ed degrees look down on them because they have not succeeded in the educational world and do not see the value in the knowledge people gain outside schools.  It is not that workers are jealous of the life-styles of more educated people, but the status hierarchy of education that devalues what those without college credentials know and asks those who are not experts to defer to the experts.  The existence other opportunities for people without college degrees is critical to diminishing the elitism associated with higher education.

This paper is just confounding. Does it EVER correct misstatements by politicians? Donald Trump's victory was not "one of the biggest Electoral College victories in history." This is basic stuff, New York Times! Both of Ronald Reagan's victories (1980, 1984), Bill Clinton's victories (1992, 1996), AND Barack Obama's victories (2008, 2012) were by larger electoral margins than Trump's. AND Trump lost the popular vote by a larger margin than 8 presidents have won! Come on. Don't let these kinds of blatant misstatements (lies?) stand. You are the newspaper of record, and you're allowing disinformation as strong as that injected into this past election to stand and proliferate.

To the topic at hand, is anyone seriously surprised by the news that not just the DNC but RNC was hacked, in part to influence this election? The question is, why did the US media actively participate in spreading the propaganda and disinformation that this hack of the Democrats produced? Why wasn't there more pushback, more critical articles, more skepticism about not just the hacked and leaked material, but the reasons why it was hacked and released, and how it might be functioning in conjunction with all the fake news, the misinformation and disinformation, and the blatant lies being spread regularly by politicians? The US media fell down on the job again and again. I'm glad the president is calling for a report, but it's a bit late, no?
There's always time for impeachment. Better late than never. And maybe we can see what a lawsuit against the electoral college results will bring us in the Supreme Court.
I fear the New York Times is not the paper it used to be.

Yup. Only about 26% of eligible voters "cast" votes for Trump. And since the margins were so low in the key states that handed the E.C. win to Trump, the high probability of Russian hacking, and so many dirty tricks (vote purging, etc.) in GOP-controlled states, I question that percentage as well.

With all due respect to the NYT, the Washington Post has just released an article this evening which reveals a recent (and now leaked) CIA report which concludes that not only did Putin hack the DNC, but that his goal was to throw the election to Trump.

If this is true, We the People need to see all the evidence without further delay. This could be an order of magnitude greater than Watergate - involving a hostile foreign power hijacking an American presidential election.

Of course Putin would like to see Trump over Hillary. Not only is Trump an open admirer of Putin and his authoritarian methods, he's a shallow narcissist and political ignoramus who would be putty in Putin's skilled KGB-skilled hands.

And wouldn't it be just like Trump, the quintessential blowhard egomaniac, to tip his hand in publicly suggesting late last July that Russia could help find Hillary's "missing 30,000 e-mails".

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/07/28/us/politics/donald-trump-russia-clinto...

Now it's all starting to make sense.

Trying to draw a comparison between the discussions among political party leaders who favor one candidate over another and the potential involvement of a hostile foreign power in helping one candidate win the general election is just plain asinine and serves to trivialize a much more serious and threatening situation.

Besides, if anyone was stealing anything in the Democratic primary, it was Bernie temporarily joining a political party of which he was never before a part, in order to steal its apparatus so he could run for President. Therefore, where stealing is concerned, and if this Russian connection turns out to have the very serious implications that it might, there is more of a similarity, really, between Sanders and Trump.

Even so, Sanders' temporary Democrat card is nothing compared to the threat of what this Trump connection to Russia might foretell.

Statements after statements without substance. Please provide a list of irresponsible governance by the President. The word fits better to Congress. (One item I concede would be the drone war - but Repugnants love that stiff even better,

So Exxon chief Rex Tillerson was all set to do a $500 Billion oil deal with Putin, until Obama's Russian's sanctions killed the deal. Then Russia intervenes in our election to get Trump elected, and now Rex Tillerson is Trump's top choice for Secretary of State. Coincidence? I'm betting those sanctions will be lifted quickly under a Trump administration. Always follow the money

“The election ended a long time ago in one of the biggest Electoral College victories in history."

I'm beginning to become greatly annoyed at statements like this. Out of the 54 elections using the current Electoral College system, only 10 have been closer than this one. The myth the GOP is attempting to perpetuate is that the election was some sort of landslide. It is not even nearly true but they continue to live in their "post-fact" universe.

If the Russians' intent was to undermine public confidence in the election, then I imagine that they have succeeded.  The shadow hanging over Trump as president is simply this: if it comes out that he or his campaign colluded with the Russians in any way, his presidency is toast.  But, trying to keep this in perspective: I don't think that very many people paid any attention to the hacked e-mails which were mostly boring; nor do I think that the ca. 80,000 people in Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin, who provided Trump with his victory in the electoral college, were much affected by those e-mails.  They were angry about very different things.
The people who provided Trump victory werew those who were indifferent or faded away at the end and could have made the difference for Clinton.

According to MIT Prof. Ron Rivest & UC Berkeley Prof. Philip Stark...."the national results could be tipped by manipulating the vote count in a relatively small number of jurisdictions — a few dozen spread across a few key states. We know that the vast majority of local elections officials have limited resources to detect or defend against cyber attacks. And while pre-election polls have large uncertainties, they were consistently off. And various aspects of the preliminary results, such as a high rate of under votes for president, have aroused suspicion." Still Time for an Election Audit, 11/18/2016 – USA Today. Also note Wisconsin hasn’t voted a Republican presidential candidate into office since 1984, Michigan since 1988. All of Wisconsin’s major polls, predicted a Clinton win by significant margins: Remington Research: Clinton 49%, Trump 41% (11/06/16); Loras College: Clinton 44%, Trump 38%(11/04/16); Marquette Law: Clinton 46%, Trump 40% (11/02/16); Public Policy: Clinton 48%, Trump 41% (11/02/16). Aided by redistricting Republicans took more seats in Michigan even when Democrats won the majority of votes; a scenario replayed in GOP-controlled states. See http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/wisconsin. AND https://ballotpedia.org/Redistricting_in_Michigan

Voters had their minds made up long before the election.

Either pro Republican or Democrat. The same result would have happened without Russian influence.
Actually data show that there was voter shifting in last weeks of campaign

"The American people should be allowed to vote again."

Crazy as this sounds, if we find that Russia tipped the scales, and Trump's people in any way colluded with Russia, how could we possibly not have a redo? Otherwise the next four years we'll be "led" by a totally illegitimate President. And that's not saying anything about his obvious breach of the emolument principle in the Constitution. The very integrity of our nation is at stake here. Are we a nation of laws or not?

The problem is that enough of the American people fell hook, line and sinker for all of the hacked information (which became propaganda) and false news that they elected someone who is highly unqualified to be president.  It's devastating to know that the Russians have the ability to play this country so well.  It's time to do some serious introspection as a country.

News Flash for Daniel Yakoubian:  You have elected Donald Trump.  Neither our president nor Mrs. Clinton is a failure.  Their many accomplishments, especially those of Pres. Obama in running down Bin Laden; lifting the country out of the deepest (Republican) recession since the Great Depression, and rebuilding the U.S. auto industry.  The stock market under President Obama has risen to new record highs, and millions of jobs have been created.  Twenty million Americans now have health care insurance who never had it before.  The Republicans have never passed legislation that has benefited millions of Americans such as Medicare and Social Security; those programs were conceived by Democrats.  Republicans have created nothing to benefit working class Americans on this level.  And they probably never will.  So we're not blaming Russians for anything quite yet and until we know the truth about their possible involvement in our election, we will withhold judgement.  But I doubt our President would launch this investigation if he did not have some evidence of Russian interference.  You sound like a very bitter person.  Maybe you, too, should wait for the results of the investigation before you label it a joke.  The joke may be on you.

The winning party that now controls the Executive and Legislative branches have no motive whatsoever to introduce doubt about the legitimacy of the election, no matter how egregious the acts of the Russian government were.  They are partisans first and Americans last.

Hacking, shmacking. So Russia interfered. Do don't think its intelligence doesn't know what's going on here? What we should be concerned about is that so many Americans, ignorant of history - both world and our own - can be duped by shysters in their own government (and for whom many voted!) into believing anything fed to them, and enough vote for, and give legitimacy to, what is obvious to any intelligent person, a potential dictator.

The wisdom of the willfully uneducated is what got us into this elephant dung in the first place, orchestrated by the Republican Party, a party that never saw a bottom-feeder, or any dim-bulb it didn't like and dupe into voting against its own interests.

Anyone who can read, should look at Hanna Arendt's "On Totalitarianism" and our Founding Fathers', "the Federalist." Neither were made into films or TV Movies of the Week, but well worth the effort to get to know. One book already made into two films, but truly worth the exertion to read, is George Orwell's "1984." It may already be too late to read them and gain wisdom, but at least buy them before they're banned - possibly - so you can eventually see that the joke is on you, folks.
Very well said, sir.

Out of eligible voters only 26% voted for Trump -- and with the probability our voting system was hacked, I even question that. Quote: “We know that the national results could be tipped by manipulating the vote count in a relatively small number of jurisdictions — a few dozen spread across a few key states. We know that the vast majority of local elections officials have limited resources to detect or defend against cyber attacks. And while pre-election polls have large uncertainties, they were consistently off. And various aspects of the preliminary results, such as a high rate of under votes for president, have aroused suspicion." See "Still Time for an Election Audit” – 11/18/2016 – USA Today, by MIT Prof. Ron Rivest & UC Berkeley Prof. Philip Stark

Trump and his cronies should be prosecuted as traitors. And according to penal law 18 U.S. Code § 2381 - Treason:
Whoever, owing allegiance to the United States, levies war against them or adheres to their enemies, giving them aid and comfort within the United States or elsewhere, is guilty of treason and shall suffer death, or shall be imprisoned not less than five years and fined under this title but not less than $10,000; and shall be incapable of holding any office under the United States.

The Russians play chess. President Obama plays basketball.

The goal of the Kremlin was to undermine confidence in the election and simultaneously assist a Trump victory?

If so, then the the latest move by the White House is everything the Kremlin could hope for -- to further undermine confidence in the legitimacy of the election and of the results. A weakened presidency is just what the Russians wanted. President Obama is handing it to them on a silver platter.
You missed the part about Trump's Team playing footsie with these people. His manager Paul Manafort was up to his eyeballs in shady business there. Why do you think he quit?

Hunh? - a 3 million vote loss in the Popular Vote just handed Trump a weakened Presidency.

Obama is about to sink a 3 pointer at the buzzer. You still haven't figured out that this guy is a tactical genius have you. He's been end-arounding the Reps for 8 years.

And a properly informed and educated electorate is the foundation of Democracy.

We should all stand united in the everlasting fight of obtaining the truth. The people, government and press should pursue this goal collectively above all else, regardless if the topic is as important as the presidential election or as common as the latest winner of popularity contest.

Without a true north of pursuing the truth, then any simple, false, and biased statement will due to suffice the claim of being informative and the "news" or the "truth".

The question I have is how much did Donald Trump know about any of this?  He invited the Russians to hack Hillary Clinton's e-mails and they obliged or had already obliged.  To me this whole revelation should be grounds for overturning the election results.  There has been interference from a foreign power in the election process, and Trump may have been complicit - we should not forget that his top advisor at one point was a man who worked with Russian politicians.  If it can be shown that  Paul Manafort had any knowledge of this tampering whatsoever, and remained silent, then he committed treason, and if he passed any information along to Donald Trump who remained silent, then he too committed an act of treason, by conspiring with a foreign government to influence an election. Now is the time to act before Donald Trump takes the oath of office.  This cannot and should not be dismissed as an election prank or political dirty tricks, it is far too serious for that.

We have two things set to happen coming up--the Electors meeting on Dec. 19 and the results being certified in Congress in early January. I think if we can get the damning evidence out by the time of the certification of the vote in Congress, we might be able to stop this charade of an election.

If this is indeed the case. then Trump should prove his patriotism by admitting he won under questionable (at best) circumstances, and cede his status as president elect. Another election should be held after the holidays.

Now, more than ever, we need full financial disclosure from Mr. Trump. His tax returns are only part of the puzzle ... we really need to know his current level of corporate indebtedness and to whom he owes that money. The parties in possession of that debt may, in the near future, be the drivers of our foreign policy.
HOW are you going to get that? He's not giving you or anyone else anything.

I fear President-elect Trump's disdain for the intel community conclusions about Russian hacking signals a Cheney style effort by the Trump administration, led by its Moscow friendly General Nuisance (Michael Flynn) to silence independent analytic thinking from the intelligence community and to purge the State Department and its Foreign Service of anyone who might offer "reality based" advice on foreign affairs, rather than slavishly echo tweet based foreign policy.

Official unemployment is down, but unemployment + underemployment / residual unemployment still sits at 10%. And structural unemployment -- reflected in the huge declines in labor force participation -- remains high. Much of the job creation during the Obama years has been in the low-paying service sector, and many of those jobs that were "created" were actually the splitting of one 40-hour-a-week jobs into two 27-hour-a-week jobs, as employers endeavored to circumvent the ACA mandate. Moreover those jobs are almost entirely concentrated in big metro areas.

I don't "hate" Obama. I sure wish he were remaining President. But we need to stop telling people everything is fine. It's NOT fine. A lot of people are struggling. Millennials are shouldering $1.3 trillion in student debt, yet with 4-year degrees we make what our parents did with high school diplomas. The white working class has been decimated in rural and exurban areas, and the jobs that replaced those lost to mechanization and outsourcing haven't returned to their communities and don't offer the same compensation.

There are two Americas, and the divide is growing very rapidly. Pretending otherwise only infuriates those who are living in the America that's been losing in the 21st century economy.

On 11/12 and 11/13 I submitted the following comment to this NYT forum:

It is impossible for so many polls to be so very wrong.
There is always a margin of error, but in this case those margins were always within reason.
The number of polls taken was very high. The polls were very consistent in their conclusions.
I maintain that ANYTHING can be hacked and I say this from a background in information technology.

This election was hacked and it is to be hoped that somewhere some capable group or organization will take up the task of proving this to be or not to be the case. Let chips fall ..... wherever.

The Freedom of Information Act should be applied to study the system analysis for the compilation of voting results and applied to the study and examination of the software developed for the implementation of the system itself.
Modifying numbers to meet predetermined outcomes is certainly possible.
In fact examination of just 4 or 5 important states could well suffice.
Another question: Where was the system and the software developed and what specific entities where involved in this effort. Did it have backdoors.

Trump decided to run for president - a great surprise to the world at large - and he did so because he knew that he would win.
His entire outrageous and offensive campaign, his demeaning attitude toward many groups of persons, and his blatant over-confidence and swagger was possible because he knew he would win.
Rigged? He knew for sure.
Q.E.D. Anyone.

MNW, I couldn't agree with you more. Who and how can this be investigated is the question. This would be a substantial undertaking and based on the fact that the government will now be controlled by the beneficiaries, it is highly unlikely there will be an accounting. This is like living in a bad movie.

Yep. Look at the polls for the states that if flipped for Trump would seal the E.C. Wisconsin hasn’t voted a Republican presidential candidate into office since 1984, Michigan since 1988. Yet all of Wisconsin’s major polls, predicted a Clinton win by significant margins: Remington Research: Clinton 49%, Trump 41% (11/06/16); Loras College: Clinton 44%, Trump 38%(11/04/16); Marquette Law: Clinton 46%, Trump 40% (11/02/16); Public Policy: Clinton 48%, Trump 41% (11/02/16). GOP-led states put in place new voter restrictions controlled 70% of the E.C., yet only 26% of eligible voters voted for Trump. (A number I now question if our insecure "hackable" voting machines. http://www.270towin.com/2016-polls-clinton-trump/wisconsin

Of course, there are many troubling things in this article, but as an American presidential history buff, one I find particularly galling: "The election ended a long time ago in one of the biggest Electoral College victories in history." This statement from Trump's transition team.

Here is a list of presidents since 1900 alone who have won the electoral college by larger margins than Trump: T. Roosevelt, Taft, Wilson, Harding, Coolidge, Hoover, F.D. Roosevelt, Eisenhower, Johnson, Nixon, Reagan, G.H.W. Bush, Clinton, and Obama.

But, really, the Electoral College hasn't voted yet, so there's still time for Trump not to have won it at all.

His electoral margin was 12th lowest out of 57 elections -- and out of eligible voters only about 26% voted for Trump and I question that veracity given that our highly insecure voting machines could have easily been hacked by the Russians.
